ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Great class overall. Instructor is VERY knowledgeable in all aspects of course topics, and provides a great learning environment that is conducive to students' questions and short discussions along the way.

More rigorous interaction between readings and class lectures would improve the course. Weekly assignment had little bearing on the class and not receiving grades on those assignments was a missed opportunity for skill building in writing/analysis ect.

I think it would be helpful if there was more cohesion between the readings and the material presented in class, and if there was more opportunity for students/teacher to discuss the readings in class. There wasn't really much incentive to do the reading....In general, I think the class would be more engaging if there was more back-and-forth, as I think many classmates have great perspectives from their own experience that would be interesting and relevant.It would also help if the individual classes were more structured/organized in terms of what material would be covered, and then if the class session stuck to that plan.

The course material was very interesting and well-presented; hearing from someone involved in the day-to-day work of planning was invaluable. I do wish that perspective had been balanced by a bit more feedback on class assignments and a focus on the tools and process for assessing different plans on our own. I found it most helpful when David ran through his decision-making or evaluative process, so more attention on this, and on how to weigh different factors according to context, would have been great.
I hope the connections between reading, lecture, and assginments can be stronger.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Kooris' lectures were interesting and engaging.

Very knowledgeable and approachable professor and TA, freedom to write about pretty much whatever you want on reading responses and term paper, very interesting course material with applicability to local issues.
I gained a much greater understanding of how urban/regional planning fit into the political process
David has a lot of professional insight into city planning and can provide first-hand examples of many of the concepts taught in class.
Getting practical information about urban planning. I think more courses should teach students the more pragmatic aspects of the subject.
Kooris' breadth of knowledge is apparent in the course lectures. He is energetic and passionate, and that makes the class more enjoyable.
Lectures were very helpful due to the amount of visuals Kooris was able to show us to compliment the things he was saying.
The flexibility and causal format of class time made it easy to have discussion based on particular interests.

Real examples and lecturer experience and in-depth knowledge on regional issues was great. More opportunity to engage lecturer would improve understanding of these issues --- ie more time to analyze decisions rather than just hearing about what happened would make the class more challenging and beneficial.

The first few lectures were awesome. I think that's what Kooris is really into and what many of the students found most interesting. I actually think that if the entire class was structured around planning lessons and techniques that were used during the development of the New York Metropolitan area, it would be far more interesting and useful.
Kooris is very knowledgeable, so it was fun to get his perspective on specific issues. The topics we covered were also very current, interesting and relevant.
I really enjoyed to focus on the northeast& the open nature of discussions.
The breadth of material and Prof. Kooris's wealth of knowledge and experience.
easy to learn a little material in a field I have no prior experience with
First-hand perspective into the planning process.
The professor really knows the course material. He's really well informed and prepared to answer anything related to the course.

The lectures in this course were interesting and useful because the instructor has many years of experience in urban and regional planning in the Northeastern US as well as in other regions, so he is a wealth of knowledge about the realities of planning practice. The lectures incorporated case studies from his work on various projects and initiatives, and in general the material was very up-to-date.
Survey of urban planning topics.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The lectures are hit-or-miss. I much preferred the sessions that addressed broad themes and those about which Kooris was either passionate or better prepared. Several sessions got stuck in the weeds or suffered from what felt like a lack of energy/preparation on the professor's part. This is understandable, given that Kooris has a full day job in addition to teaching, but the course does suffer for it.
Three hour once-a-week evening format can be grueling, though I understand why Prof. Kooris does it as a result of his own time constraints. No complaints other than that.

I think the structure of the semester needs cohesion. I didn't get much out of the readings or weekly responses, especially since they were disconnected from each other and the content of that week's lecture. And then the final paper completely stands apart from everything else; it feels like something I could have written with or without the course, rather than drawing on the concepts and knowledge I have gained this semester.
Lectures can get lost on tangents. It is hard to see some lectures as valuable or building on previous material.

The assigned readings didn't seem to have much thought put into them in that they were often too long to be able to finish on time, and then other weeks we wouldn't have any readings. If the readings were reasonable for each week, then I would have been more likely to do them. Also if we had discussed them more in class there would have been more incentive to do it.Kooris could also be hard to reach, which is understandable given his full-time job elsewhere. But it would make the final paper more fulfilling and probably better if we had easier access to the professor.Overall the course could be better organized. Having dinner consistently in class would definitely make it more enjoyable given its Thursday evening meeting time. If the slides were more oriented to note-taking that would also be beneficial, as at times it was difficult to follow along with the professor if he was talking on a tangent for 20 minutes.
None really, aside from better coordination of if/when food will be ordered... 3 hour lecture that starts at 5:30pm is rough if you haven't eaten dinner.
More clarity of concepts and terms.
Three hours of lecture is a bit much -- more opportunity for interaction with students and problem solving/analysis of cases/projects would be helpful. Perhaps small group work would be beneficial.

As the semester wore on, the 3 hour evening lectures, with little to no student interaction, became drawn out and boring. Mixing it up with some class discussion or interactive lessons is much needed.

I think just more integration/cohesion in the materials of the course. It would be great if they built upon each other somewhat, and if there was more connection between the readings and the lectures. Having more time for student participation, and more facilitated, semi-structured discussions.
No matter who the lecturer is - 2 hours is too long to listen to someone without a break.
The course would be more engaging with more discussion and student involvement.
could definitely make this course more hands-on. maybe some exercises emphasizing real-world application of the lecture material. this is a professional school, after all.
Clarify/frequency of feedback and criteria. Examples of successful papers, for instance, would have been really helpful in visualizing how the final paper should look.

The lectures. It's really hard to pay attention to a 3 straight hours lecture. I would recommend making them more interactive, have discussions, make the students participate more. If not, after the first hour or hour and a half, students start to loose attention.There is no feedback throughout the whole semester (with the exception of the exploratory paper). We did not get any grades on any of the weekly article summaries and only got feedback on our exploratory paper for our final project. This makes it hard to realize how is your performance during the semester and also makes it hard to outline a final paper.

The format of the lecture over the three-hour class period was somewhat tiring. Interspersing more class discussion and problem-solving into the course would help greatly to make it more interesting and valuable. I had the sense that most of the other students had a lot of relevant academic and work experience, but there were not many opportunities for discussion and learning from one another.
Connection between different aspects of the course.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: No lab section, but I think the second half (or last third) of class would have been better used through small group discussions based around case studies or some other participatory activity.
Needs more discussions on readings.
N/A
As stated above, more discussion in the class would be helpful.
can encourage more interaction and discussion.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I took this course out of personal curiosity, not really any close relationship to my career interests. I really enjoyed it, though, and it made me think more critically about where I want to live when I graduate - knowing more about the regional and local planning processes as well as climate and transit plans and financing will be very helpful to make sure that the community where I someday buy property will be somewhat predictable for the coming decades. It made me want to be on my local zoning board, that's for sure.

I'm an undergrad with an interest in urban planning, and have been constantly disappointed by the meager offerings on the subject in Yale College. I'm hoping to pursue either a Masters in City Planning or perhaps a graduate history degree focusing on urban topics, so I was very happy to see this course being offered. I wish there were more like it at Yale.
It was a good introduction to urban planning for me.
My background is in industrial ecology, and I am trying to learn how cities and regional areas develop and change over time to understand material flows and stocks.

I was interested in learning a bit about urban planning to see if I wanted to pursue it further. I'm still pretty unsure about it though. Some parts were very interesting but the course didn't exactly inspire me.

Just a personal interest in urban planning. I like the work happening at the city level, and hope to support this somehow in my career -- maybe by working for a city, or keeping up with what cities are doing and supporting that.
I'm interested in green urban planning and this course was a solid introduction to the material from a practitioner's standpoint.
only tangentially, but still, it was useful background to have

This course was a great introduction to planning practice, and it gave me a sense of other classes that I might take and skills that I should further develop in order to pursue planning as a career. I would be interested to know how it fits with or complements the other planning classes offered at F&ES.
urban planning.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I was curious about land use planning generally and this was the most interesting and broad survey available.
I'm interested in urban design and urban planning.
I plan to pursue urban planning-related work after graduation.
I'm interested in urban planning

I took a city& regional planning course in undergrad and fell it love with the topic. I wanted to learn about current growth/development trends and spend some time exploring the topic of military base closures and reuse of land.
See question 17
Because of my interest in urban planning and the workhappening at city levels.
General interest.
i had an empty slot, and he was a good lecturer
Because I'm interested in urban planning and wanted to get an introductory course.

Urban and regional planning is a career field that interests me and I am considering taking more classes in this area. Having taken this class, I see that there are diverse ways to approach planning, and this is but one perspective.
interests.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes! I would have liked to have a little more about parks or conservation easements but I know other courses do get into that.
Yes. I feel like I have a better grasp of current urban planning issues, especially those concerning Connecticut cities.
I learned about the politics of planning, but felt that I could have learned a lot more if the course were more focused.
I left conversant in many of the topics in city planning, but did not acquire the depth of knowledge that I had hoped for.
Sort of..it would have been fun to do an actual charrette as part of the course so we could gain hands-on insight to how that process works.
Yes! I feel like I'm walking away having learned SO MUCH, but also still curious about a few things that I want to explore in greater depth.
More opportunities to engage in debate and discuss the various projects/approaches would help skill development.
Not really. I think I should have learnt more.
Not quite. It was nice to learn subject knowledge, but it would have been nice to get more of a toolkit and more ideas about how to work on these issues.
Yes!
Somewhat. I would have appreciated the opportunity to delve into the material more deeply, through discussion or more projects (with meaningful feedback from the TF or prof).
like i said before i wish there were more hands-on applications of the material
No
Yes.
most of the topic presented in the class I have learned some before. it's a good opportunity to get it all in one class. but i am hoping to learn more in detail.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: An easy and relaxed 5th course for your schedule. Not overly demanding, and the good lectures are really fun and informative. The class has probably changed the way I view and interact with urban spaces.
It's interesting and probably valuable personally as well as professionally, and there's not a huge workload. I liked it.

I think the course is good for students with all levels of background in urban planning, and for those with no background at all but a strong interest in developing one. If you are looking for a course that is very structured, with regular assignments that seek objective answers, this is not for you. But as a forum to discuss urban issues with a very knowledgeable and approachable professor with real-world experience, this course delivers. I was very satisfied.
The course is more geared toward those without any background in planning
Make sure to do the readings to come in with questions to ask. This should generate more discussion.
Very chill course, interesting topics and professor, but can be disorganized

Keep up with the readings because Kooris refers to them regularly throughout his lectures (but does not delve into in-depth discussion); readings will help keep you focused on important topics covered in lecture. Make sure to nail down your paper topic early on; Kooris is more than happy to help students get in touch with people.

If you want to hear about regional development in CT and urban planning from a practioner than its a good class. If you want to engage in a more analytical debate about planning approaches and strategies, this is not the right class to take.
The readings are completely unnecessary as far as your grade goes, but if you want to actually learn from thecourse then you should do them.
It's great ! Bring a snack& an iced coffee.
Good introduction to regional and urban planning, but does not go into depth into any single concept/topic.
Start thinking about your final project ahead of time, so you canget feedback on it.

Get started on research for the final paper early, in order to get the most out of it.This class is a great opportunity to planning-related read articles that interest you. If possible, talk with other members of the class about their articles and news sources. This type of discussion was a small part of the class, and it was very valuable.
